--- John Arrowwood <jarrowwx@...> wrote:
> >From: Mitchell Timin <zenguyuno@...>
> >
> >Ken wrote:
> >
> > > By the way, performance gains in crossover will
> have
> > > almost no
> > > effect on performance in general, so it's not
> really
> > > worth too much
> > > effort trying to optimize crossover.  In every
> > > experiment I've seen
> > > except the very simplest, NEAT takes up a tiny
> > > fraction of
> > > computation time.  It's the evaluations that are
> > > expensive.
> >
> >Each evaluation requires the operation (or
> >computation) of the neural net itself, i.e., giving
> it
> >some inputs, and progagating the signals through
> the
> >network.  When you studied the time required for
> >evaluation did you separate it into time for
> >problem-specific code vs. neural net computation
> code?
> >  For a complex network with many connections that
> >might be substantial.
> 
> How would that distinction be helpful?  Are you
> thinking that there might be 
> ways of optimizing the network computation step? 
> And you want to know 
> whether the effort is worthwhile?  For some domains,
> it would be...

In order to compare NEAT to other approaches, the
processing time to compute the network is important. 
For example, is NEAT fast enough to use a NEAT-evolved
network in a real time application?

In doing neuroevolution the time to compute the
network can be significant.  It is possible to have a
fairly simple fitness function requiring many neurons
and many connections to optimize it.  In such a
situation the time to complete the evolution will be
strongly affected by the computation time for the
network.  I don't mean something as simple as XOR of
course, but it could be an algebraic function of 4
variables which it is desired to approximate closely
by an ANN.  That function might compute in much less
time than processing the network.


=====
Mitchell Timin
http://annevolve.sourceforge.net
